channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: At least 17 dead in Tanzania collapse
item.description: At least 17 people are dead and 30 feared trapped under debris a day after a 16-story building collapsed in Dar es Salaam, the Tanzania Red Cross Society said Saturday.

item.title: Police: Principal killed in Pakistan attack
item.description: A principal was killed and eight other people were injured in a grenade and gun attack on a school in the Pakistani city of Karachi, a police spokesman said Saturday.

item.title: Musharraf: Charges are 'trumped up'
item.description: The Taliban want him dead. Many want him in jail.

item.title: 28 die in blast at Chinese coal mine
item.description: A gas explosion at a northeastern Chinese coal mine killed 28 people, China's state-run Xinhua news agency reported Saturday.

item.title: Khmer Rouge leader deemed fit for trial
item.description: The most senior surviving Khmer Rouge leader, Nuon Chea, has been declared fit for trial by a United Nations-backed court in Cambodia, the agency said Friday.

item.title: 83 miners trapped in Tibet; none found
item.description: Rescuers have yet to find any survivors or bodies Saturday after a landslide that buried 83 workers at a gold mine in the Tibet Autonomous Region, reported Xinhua, the Chinese state-run news agency.

item.title: Afghans say airstrike killed civilians
item.description: An investigation is under way into whether civilians were killed as a result of a coalition airstrike in Afghanistan, a spokesman for the International Security Assistance Force said Saturday.

item.title: Italy's president 'won't go early'
item.description: Italy's President Giorgio Napolitano said Saturday that he will not stand down early, as Italy tries to find a way out of a political deadlock which has prevented it from forming a government since elections last month.

item.title: Bank of Cyprus haircut 'could be 60%'
item.description: Wealthy depositors in the Bank of Cyprus could face losses of as much as 60 per cent -- far in excess of what had been expected -- as the country scrambles to save what is left of its stricken banking sector.

item.title: Aid fears after coup in C.A.R.
item.description: Since a coup in the Central African Republic, 200 people have been injured. Now aid groups fear a humanitarian crisis.

item.title: Scores rescued from Latvian ice floes
item.description: More than 500 people were stranded Friday on two ice floes that broke away and began drifting off the coast of Latvia, rescue officials said.

item.title: WTC materials to be sifted for remains
item.description: New York City will begin sifting April 1 through 590 cubic yards of material from the World Trade Center site in search of human remains, the city announced Friday.

item.title: 7,000 warned of potential HIV exposure
item.description: Some 7,000 patients of a Tulsa, Oklahoma, dental practice were being notified they could have been exposed to HIV and hepatitis over the past six years, health authorities said Thursday.

item.title: Earth to space station in just six hours
item.description: In six hours -- roughly eight times faster than usual -- a spacecraft with three crew members jetted up from Earth to the International Space Station, where they'll remain through September.

item.title: Four arrested in Libya rape case
item.description: Two British female activists were raped two days ago in the eastern city of Benghazi and four suspects have been arrested, Libyan officials said Thursday.

item.title: Navy SEAL killed in training accident
item.description: A U.S. Navy SEAL killed in a training accident this week in Arizona belonged to the same elite squad that includes those chosen to go after Osama bin Laden in Pakistan two years ago, a source said.

item.title: Doctor accused of killing 7 to free beds
item.description: A Brazilian doctor appeared in court for allegedly killing seven patients to free up hospital beds in the southeast city of Curitiba.

item.title: Camera's 5,000 miles under sea trip
item.description: Erin Burnett interviews the owner of an underwater camera lost during a 2007 Hawaiian vacation and found in Taiwan.

item.title: Pope's gestures strike fire in hearts
item.description: Steven Avella says Pope Francis has used bold gestures to alert the world that changes are to come.

item.title: Gay rights opponents' last argument
item.description: Paul Waldman says it's ridiculous for those who oppose gay marriage to say that it may adversely affect straight marriage.

item.title: Why 2013 must be victory for girls
item.description: Following the attempted murder of teenage Pakistani schooling activist Malala Yousufzai, former UK prime minster Gordon Brown says world leaders must ensure 2013 is the year when girls' education rights are won.

item.title: Did we learn nothing from Newtown?
item.description: Many people thought that the massacre of 20 young school children and six educators by a gunman wielding an assault weapon would change the terms of the debate over firearms regulation.

item.title: The story behind 'What Ali Wore'
item.description: Maybe it's the way he leans into the camera or his impeccably tailored suits, but something about "What Ali Wore" has captured the public's imagination.

item.title: Why FB phone doesn't make sense
item.description: Facebook is holding an Android-related press event next week and already the Internet is in a tizzy. Could this be the rumored, mythical, magical Facebook phone?

item.title: Is President Petraeus likely?
item.description: William Doyle says when public figures screw up and offer a sincere apology, we'll give them a second chance.

item.title: Kenyan court upholds Kenyatta win in disputed poll
item.description: The Kenyan Supreme Court rules to uphold Uhuru Kenyatta's narrow victory in the country's presidential election, dismissing a challenge by his chief rival.

item.title: Rival Odinga's petition dismissed
item.description: Kenya's Supreme Court upholds election of Uhuru Kenyatta as president.

item.title: Kenyatta: A man of complexities
item.description: The election of Uhuru Kenyatta is a storybook ending for the son of Kenya's first president.

item.title: Mandela 'breathing without difficulty'
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela is breathing without difficulty in a hospital, where he is responding to treatment for pneumonia, his spokesman said Saturday.

item.title: Mandela 'responding positively'
item.description: Nelson Mandela is "responding positively" to treatment after he was readmitted to a hospital for a recurring lung infection.

item.title: Youth call Mandela revered
item.description: Dan Rivers looks at the plight of youth looking for jobs in Nelson Mandela's old Soweto neighborhoods.

item.title: What does Mandela mean to you?
item.description: To mark Nelson Mandela's birthday, we asked what the former South African president means to you. The response on social media has been overwhelming.

item.title: U.S. plays down North Korean threats
item.description: North Korea compares the U.S. with a "boiled pumpkin" vulnerable to attack from a foreign foe -- but Washington says the recent threats and insults are being treated as "warmongering rhetoric."

item.title: Annihilation threat 'normal' for S. Korea
item.description: As winter recedes, winds whip through downtown Seoul and chill the crowds of commuters on their way home. The sun is dropping and the pale golden light streams between tall buildings. A girl smiles as she chats excitedly on her cell phone. Men in black suits cluster on a street corner debating their happy hour destination.

item.title: Kim in threat to 'settle accounts'
item.description: Erin Burnett talks to Jim Clancy about Kim Jong Un ordering rockets to go on standby according to North Korean media.

item.title: How far can N. Korean missiles go?
item.description: Patricia Wu reviews North Korea's weapons and the distances they can travel.

item.title: Five things to know: N. Korea threats
item.description: Video propaganda showing the White House and Congress being blown up. Talk of hitting U.S. bases in the Pacific. The renunciation of a 60-year-old armistice that has kept the tenuous peace on the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: What now for Congo's 'Terminator'
item.description: With the surrender of a warlord, there's hope for peace in the Congo, but suffering continues, writes Sasha Lezhnev

item.title: Timing wrong for Facebook phone
item.description: Facebook is holding an Android-related press event next week and already the Internet is in a tizzy. Could this be the rumored, mythical, magical Facebook phone?

item.title: Overfishing puts oceans on the brink
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Inside the super cars of NY Auto Show
item.description: Many of the world's top super cars are being shown off at America's largest vehicle expo. CNN's Felicia Taylor reports.

item.title: Seoul shrugs off 'blackmail threat'
item.description: Despite the threats coming from Pyongyang, North Korea's neighbors seem to be free of fear and anxiety. CNN's Jim Clancy finds out why Seoul residents remain so calm.

item.title: Legacy: How soccer club fell for Africa
item.description: As fears grow for Nelson Mandela's health, his messages of peace and equality will be given center stage during an EPL football match.

item.title: Tycoon's ties with arch-foe Putin
item.description: Differences between Russian President Vladimir Putin and late tycoon Boris Berezovsky were fewer than many think, writes Damian Kudriavtsev.

item.title: Super rich sheik's space-age design
item.description: The world's richest race, Dubai World Cup, kicks off this weekend. But can money buy prestige?

item.title: Huge price tag for giant fossil egg
item.description: A giant fossilized elephant bird egg is expected to sell for $45,000 at auction in London.

item.title: Find out why this cat glows in the dark
item.description: A cyborg beetle or a pet fish engineered to glow under ultraviolet light might sound like something you'd see in a movie about the future.

item.title: Inside the super cars of NY Auto Show
item.description: Many of the world's top super cars are being shown off at America's largest vehicle expo. CNN's Felicia Taylor reports.

item.title: Rare appearance for Turin Shroud
item.description: As Christians mark Easter weekend, what may be the most famous religious relic of them all, the Turin Shroud, will make a rare TV appearance.

item.title: Google maps nuclear ghost town
item.description: Cars remain where they were crushed by falling walls two years ago, drink vending machines stand in gloomy isolation outside shuttered shops and traffic lights still blink amber in deserted streets.

item.title: One banknote = 26,000 bacteria
item.description: If you thought dirty money was only found in offshore bank accounts, check your wallet instead. But you may want to wash your hands afterward.

item.title: The world's murder capital is...
item.description: It is nighttime as a pack of masked soldiers silently moves toward the front line of a deadly shootout between law enforcement officials and unknown men in a dimly lit Honduras neighborhood.

item.title: Has ancient English king been located?
item.description: Archaeologists dug up an unmarked grave in a quiet English churchyard in search of remains of King Alfred the Great, a ninth century monarch credited with fending off the Vikings.

item.title: Super rich sheik's space-age design
item.description: The world's richest race, Dubai World Cup, kicks off this weekend. But can money buy prestige?

item.title: Find out why this cat glows in the dark
item.description: A cyborg beetle or a pet fish engineered to glow under ultraviolet light might sound like something you'd see in a movie about the future.

item.title: Huge price tag for giant fossil egg
item.description: A giant fossilized elephant bird egg is expected to sell for $45,000 at auction in London.

item.title: Somali rappers defy the bullets
item.description: The jarring sounds of war have longed echoed over Mogadishu. Now it's time for music to rock the Somali capital.

item.title: Raspberry Pi inspires hobbyists
item.description: It may not be the prettiest, but the world's smallest, cheapest personal computer is inspiring a wave of delightful DIY innovation among tech hobbyists across the planet.

item.title: FBI's intriguing UFO memo
item.description: Out of all the case files made public by the FBI online, the most popular is a memo from 1950 titled "FLYING SAUCERS," the agency said this week.

item.title: Blogger traces arms trafficking
item.description: Although Elliot Higgins has never been to Syria and has no family there, when he lost his job he found a new calling.

item.title: Spring break: Boom or bust?
item.description: When it comes to spring break, it does not always translate to a big economic boom for beach towns.

item.title: 'I am Nollywood' says Amata
item.description: Nollywood director Jeta Amata's latest movie "Black November" tells of the oil struggle in Nigeria's Niger Delta.

item.title: Opinion: N. Korea's menace
item.description: Brinkmanship is part of North Korea's stock-in trade, but the frequency of threats in Kim Jong Un's first year in charge is uncomfortably high.

item.title: The Passion of the Philippines
item.description: As Christians around the world celebrate Good Friday, zealots in the Philippines commemorate the occasion with extreme acts of penitence.

item.title: FBI's intriguing UFO memo
item.description: Out of all the case files made public by the FBI online, the most popular is a memo from 1950 titled "FLYING SAUCERS," the agency said this week.

item.title: Life in 'Venice of Africa'
item.description: In pictures: Life in the 'Venice of Africa'

item.title: Can Bieber become adult star?
item.description: Justin Bieber has been a household name since before he was old enough to drive. We listened as his voice changed and watched him trade in his purple hoodies and signature swoopy hair for low-riding pants and a more voluminous 'do.

item.title: Hats of all shapes, sizes in style
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest goes hat shopping at London's Lock and Co.

item.title: Acclaimed Arab women directors
item.description: Film-making was not an obvious career path for the young Annemarie Jacir.

item.title: Airport feline fatality sparks fury
item.description: Preeti Varma was inconsolable after seeing her pet cat crushed to death at Delhi's Indira Gandhi International Airport as the creature was loaded onto a flight to Singapore.

item.title: 2013: Year of victory for girls?
item.description: Following the attempted murder of schooling activist Malala Yousufzai, former UK prime minster Gordon Brown says world leaders must ensure girls' education rights are won.

item.title: Star cricketer in coma after attack
item.description: Jesse Ryder in critical condition after bar attack in New Zealand. CNN's Alex Thomas reports.

item.title: China's anger at 'arrogant' Apple
item.description: State-run media in China has lambasted Apple Inc. for "unparalleled arrogance" over alleged complaints about customer service in China.

item.title: Why pope washed prisoner's feet
item.description: Pope Francis went to prison to wash the feet of young inmates -- including Muslims and atheists -- on Holy Thursday.

item.title: How Syrians employ humor to survive
item.description: According to YouTube footage, some Syrians are turning unused weapons into everyday items and amusing themselves with the results.

item.title: Why oceans face collapse
item.description: Oceans make up 90% of the living volume of the planet and are home to more than one million species -- but they are under threat.

item.title: Capturing reeef beauty
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Analysis: What's Kim Jong Un up to?
item.description: North Korea's saber rattling again shook the world Wednesday. Pyongyang vowed to shut down a key military hotline with South Korea.

item.title: Why Seoul shrugs off war threats
item.description: Despite threats coming from Pyongyang, North Korea's neighbors seem to be free of fear. CNN's Jim Clancy looks at the reasons for this calm in Seoul.

item.title: Is North Korea really ready for war?
item.description: North Korea's leader called his military together declaring it might be time to go to war with the United States.

item.title: Mandela condition
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela is in "good spirits and enjoyed a full breakfast" Friday morning, the presidential office said in a statement.

item.title: Turin Shroud
item.description: What may be the most famous religious relic of them all, the Turin Shroud, will make a rare appearance on Easter Saturday -- on Italians' TV screens.

item.title: Korea threat
item.description: As winter recedes, winds whip through downtown Seoul and chill the crowds of commuters on their way home. The sun is dropping and the pale golden light streams between tall buildings. A girl smiles as she chats excitedly on her cell phone. Men in black suits cluster on a street corner debating their happy hour destination.

item.title: Syria blogger
item.description: Although Elliot Higgins has never been to Syria and has no family there, when he lost his job he found a new calling.

item.title: Justin Bieber
item.description: Justin Bieber has been a household name since before he was old enough to drive. We listened as his voice changed and watched him trade in his purple hoodies and signature swoopy hair for low-riding pants and a more voluminous 'do.

item.title: Newtown probe
item.description: U.S. school shooter Adam Lanza had hundreds of rounds of ammunition at his home and it took him less than five minutes to kill 26, investigations show.

item.title: Raspberry Pi boost
item.description: It may not be the prettiest, but the world's smallest, cheapest personal computer is inspiring a wave of delightful DIY innovation among tech hobbyists across the planet.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China media blasts 'arrogant' Apple
item.description: State-run media in China has lambasted Apple Inc. for "unparalleled arrogance" over alleged complaints about customer service in China.

item.title: 1000+ dead ducks in Chinese River
item.description: Around 1,000 duck carcasses have been found in a river in southwest China, CNN's David McKenzie has more.

item.title: Deft driver dodges decapitation
item.description: A driver in China is recovering from minor injuries after a light pole smashed through the windshield of his bus.

item.title: Vera Wang drops $500 China try-on fee
item.description: U.S. luxury bridal designer Vera Wang's first store in China has gotten off to an unfashionable start. Amid cries of discrimination, the company announced Wednesday it would scrap a controversial policy of charging customers a nearly $500 fee to try on clothes.

item.title: Jack Ma: I'm 'too old' for Internet
item.description: Chinese entrepreneur Jack Ma, who is 48, says he's too old for the Internet.

item.title: Tea, tradition and trade in China
item.description: Growing taste for Pu'er tea is boosting local economy. CNN's Steven Jiang reports.

item.title: China sentences 20 on terror charges
item.description: Two courts in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region sentenced 20 people for alleged terrorist and separatist activities on Tuesday, a spokesperson at the Kashagar Prefecture Intermediate People's Court told CNN.

item.title: China's glamorous First Lady
item.description: China's new First Lady is poised to impress--and burnish China's image overseas.
